trans-unit.source: Create a Windows Runtime 8.1 universal app on Azure App Service Mobile Apps | Microsoft Azure
trans-unit.target: Create a Windows Runtime 8.1 universal app on Azure App Service Mobile Apps | Microsoft Azure

trans-unit.source: Follow this tutorial to get started with using Azure mobile app backends for Windows Store development in C#, Visual Basic, or JavaScript.
trans-unit.target: Follow this tutorial to get started with using Azure mobile app backends for Windows Store development in C#, Visual Basic, or JavaScript.

trans-unit.source: This tutorial shows you how to add a cloud-based backend service to a Windows Runtime 8.1 universal app by using an Azure mobile app backend.
trans-unit.target: This tutorial shows you how to add a cloud-based backend service to a Windows Runtime 8.1 universal app by using an Azure mobile app backend.

trans-unit.source: Universal Windows app solutions include projects for both Windows Store 8.1 and Windows Phone Store 8.1 apps, in addition to a common shared project.
trans-unit.target: Universal Windows app solutions include projects for both Windows Store 8.1 and Windows Phone Store 8.1 apps, in addition to a common shared project.

trans-unit.source: To complete this tutorial, you need the following:
trans-unit.target: To complete this tutorial, you need the following:

trans-unit.source: An active Azure account.
trans-unit.target: An active Azure account.

trans-unit.source: If you don't have an account, you can sign up for an Azure trial and get up to 10 free mobile apps that you can keep using even after your trial ends.
trans-unit.target: If you don't have an account, you can sign up for an Azure trial and get up to 10 free mobile apps that you can keep using even after your trial ends.

trans-unit.source: For details, see <linkText>Azure Free Trial</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: For details, see <linkText>Azure Free Trial</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: [Visual Studio Community 2013] or a later version.
trans-unit.target: [Visual Studio Community 2013] or a later version.

trans-unit.source: If you want to get started with Azure App Service before you sign up for an Azure account, go to <linkText>Try App Service</linkText><title></title>. There, you can immediately create a short-lived starter mobile app in App Service—no credit card required, and no commitments.
trans-unit.target: If you want to get started with Azure App Service before you sign up for an Azure account, go to <linkText>Try App Service</linkText><title></title>. There, you can immediately create a short-lived starter mobile app in App Service—no credit card required, and no commitments.

trans-unit.source: In the [Azure portal], click Browse All > Web Apps, and then click the mobile app backend that you just created.
trans-unit.target: In the [Azure portal], click Browse All > Web Apps, and then click the mobile app backend that you just created.

trans-unit.source: In the mobile app backend, click All settings, and then under Mobile App, click Quickstart > Windows (C#).
trans-unit.target: In the mobile app backend, click All settings, and then under Mobile App, click Quickstart > Windows (C#).

trans-unit.source: Under Download and run your server project in Create a new app, click Download, extract the compressed project files to your local computer, and open the solution in Visual Studio.
trans-unit.target: Under Download and run your server project in Create a new app, click Download, extract the compressed project files to your local computer, and open the solution in Visual Studio.

trans-unit.source: Build the project to restore the NuGet packages.
trans-unit.target: Build the project to restore the NuGet packages.

trans-unit.source: Once you have created your mobile app backend, you can follow an easy Quickstart in the Azure portal to either create a new app or modify an existing app to connect to your mobile app backend.
trans-unit.target: Once you have created your mobile app backend, you can follow an easy Quickstart in the Azure portal to either create a new app or modify an existing app to connect to your mobile app backend.

trans-unit.source: In this section, you download a universal Windows app template project that is customized to connect to your Azure mobile app backend.
trans-unit.target: In this section, you download a universal Windows app template project that is customized to connect to your Azure mobile app backend.

trans-unit.source: Back in the blade for your Mobile App backend, click All settings, and then under Mobile App, click Quickstart > Windows (C#).
trans-unit.target: Back in the blade for your Mobile App backend, click All settings, and then under Mobile App, click Quickstart > Windows (C#).

trans-unit.source: Under Download and run your Windows project in Create a new app, click Download, and extract the compressed project files to your local computer.
trans-unit.target: Under Download and run your Windows project in Create a new app, click Download, and extract the compressed project files to your local computer.

trans-unit.source: (Optional) Add the universal Windows app project to the solution with the server project.
trans-unit.target: (Optional) Add the universal Windows app project to the solution with the server project.

trans-unit.source: This makes it easier to debug and test both the app and the backend in the same Visual Studio solution, if you choose to do so.
trans-unit.target: This makes it easier to debug and test both the app and the backend in the same Visual Studio solution, if you choose to do so.

trans-unit.source: With the Windows Store app as the startup project, press the F5 key to rebuild the project and start the Windows Store app.
trans-unit.target: With the Windows Store app as the startup project, press the F5 key to rebuild the project and start the Windows Store app.

trans-unit.source: In the app, type meaningful text, such as Complete the tutorial, in the Insert a TodoItem text box, and then click Save.
trans-unit.target: In the app, type meaningful text, such as Complete the tutorial, in the Insert a TodoItem text box, and then click Save.

trans-unit.source: This sends a POST request to the new mobile app backend that's hosted in Azure.
trans-unit.target: This sends a POST request to the new mobile app backend that's hosted in Azure.

trans-unit.source: Stop debugging, right-click the .WindowsPhone project, click Set as StartUp Project, and then press F5 again.
trans-unit.target: Stop debugging, right-click the .WindowsPhone project, click Set as StartUp Project, and then press F5 again.

trans-unit.source: Notice that data saved from the previous step is loaded from the mobile app after the Windows app starts.
trans-unit.target: Notice that data saved from the previous step is loaded from the mobile app after the Windows app starts.

trans-unit.source:
Add authentication to your app
Learn how to authenticate users of your app with an identity provider.
trans-unit.target:
Add authentication to your app
Learn how to authenticate users of your app with an identity provider.

trans-unit.source:
Add push notifications to your app
Learn how to send a very basic push notification to your app.
trans-unit.target:
Add push notifications to your app
Learn how to send a very basic push notification to your app.
